posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked:
Hear me out.

It would be nice if there was a way to have a ‘social’ network that is built on top of Signal, much more secure and much more privacy-focused than that wretched Book of Vomit Face many of us use for work / connecting with those who we love (who internally hate it, and long for something different).

Basically, the ability to make groups of your contacts, and have a timeline, and whatnot - but to be able to customize things like…

  • Disappearing posts
  • Custom post visibility
  • Sharing of links, etc as Timeline posts
  • The ability to respond with emoji (custom emotions) to a post (rather than that whole limit your reaction garbage to a specific set of cookie-cutter emotions)
  • Maybe even Mastodon support?

It’s SO time for a secure, encrypted social network, that isn’t another Facebook-owned piece of junk.

Maybe it’s a bit of an ambitious feature request, but it seems like little would need to be done from what Group chat already does. This would make Signal a force to be reckoned with! And the more people who use it, the less likely politicians could move society against it without consequences. Plus, being able to have a social experience where you are less likely to have employers, future employers, snoopy people, creepy companies, etc nose through your personal life events, preferences, and opinions is like… I don’t know… a thought that gives me all kinds of fuzzy warm feelings!

It would almost be like a REAL social experience, like the ones made in real life! (Who would imagine?!)

Maybe even make it as an experiment in a separate app (for those who’d rather, understandably, not want to go down that road) and test the waters before committing to adding it straight to the Signal apps itself?

Anyways, that’s my wild feature request idea. Take it, use it, bury it, whatever… Thanks for making a great app!

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
What is the use of encryption for a social network, where everyone is supposed to be able to read contributions?

Mastodon is already a censor-proof network (although some contributers try their best to censor unwanted opinions), with the only weakly censored Gab (they only censor material that violates US law, so no censorship of “hate speech”) as their biggest node.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked:
The use? Being able to to share securely on an encrypted platform that is already becoming very popular. Sometimes you want to have a community to share with that isn’t the whole world. Signal is well designed for that. But, having a large group chat makes less sense in some cases than would a social network. I think there are some great use cases for timelines/events/somewhat sharable content.

Case in point would be a large team or organization, where files, events, posts, etc could be shared and passed along within the group, but out of access of some random company’s hands.

In other words, it’s a better middle ground than the current popular social options, where you can be social 100% but you can’t be social at, say 30%. Signal is a great way to limit audience.

Mastodon is great, in many ways, but to be blunt, there’s a lower adoption rate (at least from what I’ve seen) in comparison to Signal. A lot of my friends now heavily rely on Signal. I think over time, especially with WhatsApp being controlled by FB, even more will come to use it. LINE has timeline, Telegram has channels… It would be great, in my opinion, if Signal had something social. Just my thoughts.

Maybe you should wait for Okuna, a social network which is open source, privacy orientated and ad free. But it is still in beta. Their schedule is to have the app ready by March. I prefer Signal to stay what it is: a private messenger.

https://www.okuna.io/en/home

This is way outside the scope of what Signal is and ever should be.

The entire idea behind a social network is incompatible with the idea of E2EE, no metadata, etc.

RobertCampbell:

Mastodon is great, in many ways, but to be blunt, there’s a lower adoption rate (at least from what I’ve seen) in comparison to Signal.

You can’t compare adoption rates between Signal and Mastodon because they’re entirely different things. However, adoption rate would indeed be a major problem here; a social network isn’t any good if no one uses it, and I can guarantee you no one would use it. People are locked in to Facebook and Twitter, and the people who are already avoiding those would not be inclined to join something else just because it touted security.

This is something I would absolutely hate. I always hated how FB Messenger was associated with your Facebook account.

Signal is pretty perfect as it is.

Herohtar:

This is way outside the scope of what Signal is and ever should be.

Signal should be an easy to use, end to end encrypted personal messenger and nothing more.

I believe what you’re looking for is something like Telegram Broadcast Channels.

InfoGroups / Channels / Broadcast lists Feature Requests
I am missing the possibility to create groups where only the creator can see the members and post to that group, for sending out information about events or something like that. That would be useful if you have a larger group of people to inform who do not know each other or at least are not very close to each other. This could be a teacher informing his students, or a medical practice, basically any event where you know the main person/organisation but not the other participants. I think this…

What’s super dope is Telegram let’s you link a group chat with a broadcast channel. So if someone wants to discuss a post from a broadcast channel, they can easily get to the linked group chat.

Usernames (soon to be added apparently) will go a long way to making this a possibility.
Something like www.mewe.com ?

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked: Something very similar. I know that not all Signal users want to mix chat and social, but I know that would be a lot more users if people could do something like this.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked: Looks like something good to watch. I’m not necessarily suggesting everyone be dumped into the social environment if they don’t want. But, for those of us who are kinds tied into FB for work related things, having an alternative that could function nearly the same could be really helpful (similar to Telegram Channels?). Having it as a separate app might be warranted as well.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked: I’ve never tried it. Looks interesting though.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked: I can understand that desire. I just know that there would be a lot of use cases for something like this. Like Telegram Channels, or something similar. Having this feature as a separate app that’s based off of Signal, ideally, would keep any association as purely optional, so people who prefer having jsut the messenger part could have such.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked:
I can understand the desire to keep Signal simple and focused to chat. I don’t think the idea is incompatible (just like groups isn’t). I do believe having such a social component being separate (as in a separate app which is based on Signal) would help users like yourself still have what you want out of Signal, and not being locked into an additional social service. I myself would hold the same position as you, except a part of my job requires time and work on social media - so people like myself are looking for an alternative to what’s currently out there. Signal has a lot of good things in it.

My mention of adoption rates is purely regarding the fact that Signal is becoming quite popular, and Mastodon (and many other alternative services) are relatively unknown. I think a lot of people would dump FB if they had a well-known, trusted, secure platform which they could use to do similar things. I think that there are a lot of people who would be interested in something like this.

I’m using Okuna as a beta tester now for almost six weeks and I must say that it is a pleasant experience. Certainly there are some bugs and there are not that many people yet, but I like the app and most of the UI and UX. I’m kind of curious what’s going to happen when the number of users increases.
I am a Okuna Beta user too, but I find it to be a boring platform. I use it beside MeWe, which I think is a more dynamic platform. It is easy to use for ex-Failbookers and looks pretty familiar.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked:
It definitely looks promising. The biggest challenge to any of these projects is getting the ‘mass’ of people to get off FB. People are starting to see FB for what it is. I think if they had a big name come out with a new social network, I’d think people would jump ship.

Especially if it used solid security, and had decent group/network management… That’s the biggest challenge facing people who want to get off of FB and on to something better.

Signal group chat is SO close as-is (at least for me, where I have a lot of co-workers and friends using it), but users don’t want to be bombarded with every single chat notification, and would rather have that ‘timeline’ format. All that would seemingly need to happen is have a group where you can customize notification options, and see things in a timeline like format.

And even if that required installing a second app, and linking their Signal account, I’m sure there would be a lot of users who would.

Oh, and I signed up for the beta, so I can check Okuna out.

RobertCampbell:

I think if they had a big name come out with a new social network, I’d think people would jump ship.

I don’t think so. Google tried it with it’s Google Plus, which was a great and user friendly platform, but in the end the masses stuck to Failbook.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked: True. I still wish Google Plus was around. I think the climate isn’t the same though. I think it’s a matter of good execution too, something Google didn’t do.

RobertCampbell:

All that would seemingly need to happen is have a group where you can customize notification options, and see things in a timeline like format.

You can already customize notifications in Signal and mute them if you don’t want to be spammed from a group. What additional customizations are you taking about?

Messages already appear in the order they were sent… that’s about as timeline format as you can get.

But if you think Signal’s group chats are anywhere close to a social network, maybe you don’t really want a social network at all, but just improved group chats.

By the way, don’t spam a bunch of posts in a row; if you have multiple replies, just put them all in one post to keep the thread tidy.

posts.name: Robert M Campbell
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

What additional customizations are you taking about?

Mainly just the ability to have ‘posts’ and chats based on those posts in a timeline.

Herohtar:

that’s about as timeline format as you can get.

Typically, when I think of a timeline, I think of a ‘user’ having posts (some kind of content), and then being able to have ‘chats/comments/replies’ based on those posts. That said, maybe there is another way to perform the same idea in some kind of group post?

Herohtar:

maybe you don’t really want a social network at all, but just improved group chats.

That’s kind of what I’m throwing around in my mind - if there was just a way to extend groups to do this kind of thing…

Herohtar:

By the way, don’t spam a bunch of posts in a row; if you have multiple replies, just put them all in one post to keep the thread tidy.

Sorry, I’m not used to this kind of community site, so still making a number of mistakes. I figured out how to quote individual statements. I’ll try not to do single replies to each comment.
